nodes.label: Architecture and Organization
nodes.title: Architecture and Organization
nodes.description: Architecture and Organization:

nodes.label: Digital Logic and Digital Systems
nodes.title: Digital Logic and Digital Systems
nodes.description: Digital Logic and Digital Systems: Study of binary logic and the design of digital circuits.

nodes.label: Overview and history of computer architecture
nodes.title: Overview and history of computer architecture
nodes.description: Overview and history of computer architecture: Understanding the evolution and key concepts of computer systems.

nodes.label: Combinational vs. sequential logic
nodes.title: Combinational vs. sequential logic
nodes.description: Combinational vs. sequential logic: Differentiating between logic circuits with and without memory elements.

nodes.label: Fundamental combinational
nodes.title: Fundamental combinational
nodes.description: Fundamental combinational: Basic components like logic gates (AND, OR, NOT).

nodes.label: Sequential logic building block
nodes.title: Sequential logic building block
nodes.description: Sequential logic building block: Components like flip-flops, latches enabling memory in circuits.

nodes.label: Functional hardware and software multi‐layer architecture
nodes.title: Functional hardware and software multi‐layer architecture
nodes.description: Functional hardware and software multi‐layer architecture: Understanding the interaction between hardware and software layers in a computer system.

nodes.label: Computer‐aided design tools that process hardware and architectural representations
nodes.title: Computer‐aided design tools that process hardware and architectural representations
nodes.description: Computer‐aided design tools that process hardware and architectural representations: Tools facilitating the design and analysis of digital systems.

nodes.label: High‐level synthesis
nodes.title: High‐level synthesis
nodes.description: High‐level synthesis: Automated conversion of high-level code into hardware description language.

nodes.label: Register transfer notation
nodes.title: Register transfer notation
nodes.description: Register transfer notation: Description of digital systems in terms of data transfers between registers.

nodes.label: Hardware description language
nodes.title: Hardware description language
nodes.description: Hardware description language: Languages like VHDL or Verilog for describing digital circuits.

nodes.label: System‐on‐chip (SoC) design flow
nodes.title: System‐on‐chip (SoC) design flow
nodes.description: System‐on‐chip (SoC) design flow: Methodology for designing complex integrated circuits.

nodes.label: Physical constraints
nodes.title: Physical constraints
nodes.description: Physical constraints: Limitations imposed by the physical properties of hardware components.

nodes.label: Gate delays
nodes.title: Gate delays
nodes.description: Gate delays: Time taken for signals to propagate through logic gates.

nodes.label: Fan‐in and fan‐out
nodes.title: Fan‐in and fan‐out
nodes.description: Fan‐in and fan‐out: Number of inputs and outputs a gate can handle.

nodes.label: Energy/power
nodes.title: Energy/power
nodes.description: Energy/power: Considerations for power consumption and energy efficiency in digital systems.

nodes.label: Speed of light
nodes.title: Speed of light
nodes.description: Speed of light: Physical limitation affecting the propagation of signals in hardware.

nodes.label: Machine-Level Data Representation
nodes.title: Machine-Level Data Representation
nodes.description: Machine-Level Data Representation: Understanding how data is represented at the binary level in a computer system.

nodes.label: Bits, bytes, and words
nodes.title: Bits, bytes, and words
nodes.description: Bits, bytes, and words: Basic units of digital data, where a bit is the smallest unit, a byte typically consists of 8 bits, and a word is the natural unit of data a processor can process at once.

nodes.label: Numeric data representation and number bases
nodes.title: Numeric data representation and number bases
nodes.description: Numeric data representation and number bases: Representing numbers using different bases, such as binary, decimal, octal, and hexadecimal.

nodes.label: Fixed‐point
nodes.title: Fixed‐point
nodes.description: Fixed‐point: Representing numbers with a fixed number of digits after the decimal point.

nodes.label: Floating‐point
nodes.title: Floating‐point
nodes.description: Floating‐point: Representing numbers with a variable number of significant digits and an exponent, allowing a wider range of values.

nodes.label: Signed and twos‐complement representations
nodes.title: Signed and twos‐complement representations
nodes.description: Signed and twos‐complement representations: Methods for representing negative numbers in binary, where the most significant bit (MSB) indicates the sign in signed representation, and twos-complement representation simplifies arithmetic operations.

nodes.label: Representation of non‐numeric data
nodes.title: Representation of non‐numeric data
nodes.description: Representation of non‐numeric data: Representing characters, symbols, and other non-numeric data using character encoding schemes like ASCII or Unicode.

nodes.label: Representation of records and arrays
nodes.title: Representation of records and arrays
nodes.description: Representation of records and arrays: Organizing structured data such as records (collections of related fields) and arrays (collections of data elements of the same type) in memory.

nodes.label: Assembly Level Machine Organization
nodes.title: Assembly Level Machine Organization
nodes.description: Assembly Level Machine Organization: Understanding the low-level structure and operation of a computer at the assembly language level.

nodes.label: von Neumann machine architecture
nodes.title: von Neumann machine architecture
nodes.description: von Neumann machine architecture: Basic architecture featuring a single shared memory for both data and instructions.

nodes.label: Control unit; instruction fetch, decode, and execution
nodes.title: Control unit; instruction fetch, decode, and execution
nodes.description: Control unit; instruction fetch, decode, and execution: Components responsible for fetching, decoding, and executing instructions.

nodes.label: Introduction to SIMD vs. MIMD and the Flynn taxonomy
nodes.title: Introduction to SIMD vs. MIMD and the Flynn taxonomy
nodes.description: Introduction to SIMD vs. MIMD and the Flynn taxonomy: Differentiating between Single Instruction, Multiple Data (SIMD) and Multiple Instruction, Multiple Data (MIMD) architectures based on instruction and data processing.

nodes.label: Shared memory multiprocessors/multicore organization
nodes.title: Shared memory multiprocessors/multicore organization
nodes.description: Shared memory multiprocessors/multicore organization: Systems with multiple processors/cores sharing a common memory.

nodes.label: Instruction set architecture (ISA)e.g. x86, ARM and RISC‐V
nodes.title: Instruction set architecture (ISA)e.g. x86, ARM and RISC‐V
nodes.description: Instruction set architecture (ISA)e.g. x86, ARM and RISC‐V: The set of instructions a processor can execute.

nodes.label: Instruction formats
nodes.title: Instruction formats
nodes.description: Instruction formats: Different formats used to represent instructions in machine code.

nodes.label: Data manipulation, control, I/O
nodes.title: Data manipulation, control, I/O
nodes.description: Data manipulation, control, I/O: Types of operations performed by instructions, including data processing, control flow, and input/output.

nodes.label: Addressing modes
nodes.title: Addressing modes
nodes.description: Addressing modes: Different ways of specifying the address of operands in instructions.

nodes.label: Machine language programming
nodes.title: Machine language programming
nodes.description: Machine language programming: Writing programs directly in machine code.

nodes.label: Assembly language programming
nodes.title: Assembly language programming
nodes.description: Assembly language programming: Writing programs using human-readable mnemonics that map to machine code instructions.

nodes.label: Subroutine call and return mechanisms (xref PL/language translation and execution)
nodes.title: Subroutine call and return mechanisms (xref PL/language translation and execution)
nodes.description: Subroutine call and return mechanisms (xref PL/language translation and execution): Techniques for calling and returning from subroutines in assembly language.

nodes.label: I/and interrupts
nodes.title: I/and interrupts
nodes.description: I/and interrupts : Input/output operations and mechanisms for handling interrupts.

nodes.label: Heap, static,  stack and code segments
nodes.title: Heap, static,  stack and code segments
nodes.description: Heap, static,  stack and code segments: Different memory segments used by programs, including dynamic memory (heap), static data, runtime stack, and code.

nodes.label: Memory Hierarchy
nodes.title: Memory Hierarchy
nodes.description: Memory Hierarchy:

nodes.label: Memory hierarchy: the importance of temporal and spatial locality [Shared with OS]
nodes.title: Memory hierarchy: the importance of temporal and spatial locality [Shared with OS]
nodes.description: Memory hierarchy: the importance of temporal and spatial locality [Shared with OS]: Organizes memory into levels based on speed and size, exploiting temporal and spatial locality to improve performance.

nodes.label: Main memory organization and operations
nodes.title: Main memory organization and operations
nodes.description: Main memory organization and operations: RAM serves as the main memory, accessed by the CPU for storing and retrieving data and instructions.

nodes.label: Persistent memory (e.g. SSD, standard disks)
nodes.title: Persistent memory (e.g. SSD, standard disks)
nodes.description: Persistent memory (e.g. SSD, standard disks): Includes SSDs and standard disks, used for long-term storage of data even when the system is powered off.

nodes.label: Latency, cycle time, bandwidth and interleaving
nodes.title: Latency, cycle time, bandwidth and interleaving
nodes.description: Latency, cycle time, bandwidth and interleaving: Parameters that characterize memory performance, including access time, clock cycle duration, data transfer rate, and interleaved access.

nodes.label: Virtual memory (hardware support, cross‐reference OS/Virtual Memory)
nodes.title: Virtual memory (hardware support, cross‐reference OS/Virtual Memory)
nodes.description: Virtual memory (hardware support, cross‐reference OS/Virtual Memory) : Provides an abstraction layer for managing memory resources, allowing the OS to use disk space as an extension of physical RAM.

nodes.label: Fault handling and reliability
nodes.title: Fault handling and reliability
nodes.description: Fault handling and reliability: Mechanisms to detect and recover from memory errors, ensuring system stability and data integrity.

nodes.label: Reliability (cross‐reference SF/Reliability through Redundancy)
nodes.title: Reliability (cross‐reference SF/Reliability through Redundancy)
nodes.description: Reliability (cross‐reference SF/Reliability through Redundancy): Techniques such as error coding and redundancy to enhance system reliability and fault tolerance.

nodes.label: Error coding
nodes.title: Error coding
nodes.description: Error coding:

nodes.label: Data compression
nodes.title: Data compression
nodes.description: Data compression: Techniques to reduce the size of stored or transmitted data, optimizing memory utilization and bandwidth usage.

nodes.label: Data integrity
nodes.title: Data integrity
nodes.description: Data integrity: Ensures that data remains unchanged and consistent throughout its lifecycle, safeguarding against errors and corruption.

nodes.label: Non‐von Neumann Architectures
nodes.title: Non‐von Neumann Architectures
nodes.description: Non‐von Neumann Architectures: Novel computing architectures that depart from the traditional von Neumann model, offering alternative approaches to memory and processing.

nodes.label: In‐Memory Processing (PIM)
nodes.title: In‐Memory Processing (PIM)
nodes.description: In‐Memory Processing (PIM): Performs computations directly within memory modules, reducing data movement and improving processing efficiency.

nodes.label: Cache memories [Shared with OS]
nodes.title: Cache memories [Shared with OS]
nodes.description: Cache memories [Shared with OS]: Small, fast memory units that store frequently accessed data and instructions, reducing access latency and improving CPU performance.

nodes.label: Address mapping
nodes.title: Address mapping
nodes.description: Address mapping: Techniques for translating logical addresses to physical memory locations, facilitating memory access.

nodes.label: Block size
nodes.title: Block size
nodes.description: Block size: Determines the amount of data fetched from main memory to cache in a single operation, affecting cache efficiency.

nodes.label: Replacement and store policy
nodes.title: Replacement and store policy
nodes.description: Replacement and store policy: Algorithms for managing cache contents, including eviction and data placement strategies.

nodes.label: Multiprocessor cache coherence
nodes.title: Multiprocessor cache coherence
nodes.description: Multiprocessor cache coherence: Ensures consistency of shared data across multiple caches in a multiprocessing system, preventing data inconsistencies and race conditions.

nodes.label: Interfacing and Communication
nodes.title: Interfacing and Communication
nodes.description: Interfacing and Communication:

nodes.label: I/fundamentals[Shared with OS and SPD]
nodes.title: I/fundamentals[Shared with OS and SPD]
nodes.description: I/fundamentals[Shared with OS and SPD]: Principles governing the interaction between different components, shared with operating systems and system programming.

nodes.label: Handshaking and buffering
nodes.title: Handshaking and buffering
nodes.description: Handshaking and buffering: Techniques for coordinating communication between devices and managing data flow.

nodes.label: Programmed I/O
nodes.title: Programmed I/O
nodes.description: Programmed I/O: Method where the CPU directly controls data transfer between peripherals and memory, requiring constant CPU intervention.

nodes.label: Interrupt‐driven I/O
nodes.title: Interrupt‐driven I/O
nodes.description: Interrupt‐driven I/O: Mechanism where peripheral devices interrupt the CPU to request attention, enabling asynchronous data transfer.

nodes.label: Interrupt structures: vectored and prioritized, interrupt acknowledgement [Shared with OS]
nodes.title: Interrupt structures: vectored and prioritized, interrupt acknowledgement [Shared with OS]
nodes.description: Interrupt structures: vectored and prioritized, interrupt acknowledgement [Shared with OS]: Includes vectored and prioritized interrupt mechanisms, along with interrupt acknowledgment protocols, shared with operating systems.

nodes.label: External storage, physical organization and drives [Shared with OS]
nodes.title: External storage, physical organization and drives [Shared with OS]
nodes.description: External storage, physical organization and drives [Shared with OS]: Refers to storage devices outside the CPU, such as hard drives and SSDs, with considerations for physical organization and drive characteristics, also shared with operating systems.

nodes.label: Buses fundamentals [Shared with OS and SPD]
nodes.title: Buses fundamentals [Shared with OS and SPD]
nodes.description: Buses fundamentals [Shared with OS and SPD]: Basics of bus architecture, shared with operating systems and system programming, including bus protocols and arbitration methods.

nodes.label: Bus protocols
nodes.title: Bus protocols
nodes.description: Bus protocols: Specifications defining the rules and procedures for communication between devices on a bus.

nodes.label: Arbitration
nodes.title: Arbitration
nodes.description: Arbitration: Process of resolving conflicts when multiple devices attempt to access the bus simultaneously.

nodes.label: Direct‐memory access (DMA)
nodes.title: Direct‐memory access (DMA)
nodes.description: Direct‐memory access (DMA): Technique allowing peripherals to transfer data directly to and from memory without CPU intervention, enhancing efficiency.

nodes.label: Network‐on‐chip (NoC)
nodes.title: Network‐on‐chip (NoC)
nodes.description: Network‐on‐chip (NoC): Architecture where multiple processor cores or IP blocks communicate via an on-chip network, facilitating scalable and efficient interconnectivity.

nodes.label: Functional Organization
nodes.title: Functional Organization
nodes.description: Functional Organization:

nodes.label: Implementation of simple datapaths, including instruction pipelining, hazard detection and resolution
nodes.title: Implementation of simple datapaths, including instruction pipelining, hazard detection and resolution
nodes.description: Implementation of simple datapaths, including instruction pipelining, hazard detection and resolution:

nodes.label: Control unit
nodes.title: Control unit
nodes.description: Control unit: Component responsible for directing the operation of the processor, including instruction decoding and execution control.

nodes.label: Hardwired implementation
nodes.title: Hardwired implementation
nodes.description: Hardwired implementation: Approach to building the control unit using physical circuitry, offering fast execution but limited flexibility.

nodes.label: Microprogrammed realization
nodes.title: Microprogrammed realization
nodes.description: Microprogrammed realization: Technique where the control unit's behavior is defined by microinstructions stored in control memory, offering greater flexibility at the expense of some performance.

nodes.label: Instruction pipelining
nodes.title: Instruction pipelining
nodes.description: Instruction pipelining: Technique for improving processor throughput by breaking down instruction execution into multiple stages, allowing multiple instructions to be processed simultaneously.

nodes.label: Introduction to instruction‐level parallelism (ILP)
nodes.title: Introduction to instruction‐level parallelism (ILP)
nodes.description: Introduction to instruction‐level parallelism (ILP): Exploitation of parallelism at the instruction level to enhance performance, often achieved through techniques like pipelining and superscalar execution.

nodes.label: Performance and Energy Efficiency
nodes.title: Performance and Energy Efficiency
nodes.description: Performance and Energy Efficiency:

nodes.label: Performance‐energy evaluation (introduction): performance, power consumption, memory and communication costs
nodes.title: Performance‐energy evaluation (introduction): performance, power consumption, memory and communication costs
nodes.description: Performance‐energy evaluation (introduction): performance, power consumption, memory and communication costs: Examination of performance metrics including power consumption, memory, and communication costs to assess efficiency.

nodes.label: Branch prediction, speculative execution, out‐of‐order execution, Tomasulo's algorithm
nodes.title: Branch prediction, speculative execution, out‐of‐order execution, Tomasulo's algorithm
nodes.description: Branch prediction, speculative execution, out‐of‐order execution, Tomasulo's algorithm: Techniques to improve processor performance by predicting branch outcomes, executing instructions speculatively, and reordering instructions for optimal execution.

nodes.label: Prefetching
nodes.title: Prefetching
nodes.description: Prefetching : Strategy for improving memory access performance by fetching data before it is explicitly requested.

nodes.label: Enhancements for vector processors and GPUs
nodes.title: Enhancements for vector processors and GPUs
nodes.description: Enhancements for vector processors and GPUs: Techniques tailored for vector processors and Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) to optimize performance for specific workloads.

nodes.label: Hardware support for Multithreading
nodes.title: Hardware support for Multithreading
nodes.description: Hardware support for Multithreading: Hardware-level features to facilitate concurrent execution of multiple threads for improved performance.

nodes.label: Race conditions
nodes.title: Race conditions
nodes.description: Race conditions: Situations in concurrent programming where the outcome of operations depends on the timing of their execution, potentially leading to unexpected behavior.

nodes.label: Lock implementations
nodes.title: Lock implementations
nodes.description: Lock implementations: Mechanisms used to synchronize access to shared resources in multithreaded environments.

nodes.label: Point‐to‐point synchronization
nodes.title: Point‐to‐point synchronization
nodes.description: Point‐to‐point synchronization: Point-to-Point Synchronization: Techniques for coordinating synchronization between threads to avoid race conditions and ensure data consistency.

nodes.label: Barrier implementation
nodes.title: Barrier implementation
nodes.description: Barrier implementation: Mechanisms for synchronizing multiple threads to ensure that all threads reach a designated point before proceeding.

nodes.label: Scalability
nodes.title: Scalability
nodes.description: Scalability: The ability of a system to handle increasing workloads by adding resources without sacrificing performance.

nodes.label: Alternative architectures, such as VLIW/EPIC, accelerators and other special‐purpose processors
nodes.title: Alternative architectures, such as VLIW/EPIC, accelerators and other special‐purpose processors
nodes.description: Alternative architectures, such as VLIW/EPIC, accelerators and other special‐purpose processors: Exploration of alternative hardware designs optimized for specific tasks or workloads.

nodes.label: Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS)
nodes.title: Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS)
nodes.description: Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS): Technique for adjusting the operating voltage and frequency of a processor dynamically to optimize energy efficiency.

nodes.label: Dark Silicon
nodes.title: Dark Silicon
nodes.description: Dark Silicon: The portion of a chip that cannot be powered on simultaneously due to power and thermal constraints, leading to challenges in maximizing hardware utilization.

nodes.label: Heterogeneous Architectures
nodes.title: Heterogeneous Architectures
nodes.description: Heterogeneous Architectures:

nodes.label: SIMD and MIMD architectures (e.g. General‐Purpose GPUs, TPUs and NPUs)
nodes.title: SIMD and MIMD architectures (e.g. General‐Purpose GPUs, TPUs and NPUs)
nodes.description: SIMD and MIMD architectures (e.g. General‐Purpose GPUs, TPUs and NPUs): SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) and MIMD (Multiple Instruction, Multiple Data) architectures, including General-Purpose GPUs (Graphics Processing Units), TPUs (Tensor Processing Units), and NPUs (Neural Processing Units), designed to perform parallel computations efficiently.

nodes.label: Heterogeneous memory system
nodes.title: Heterogeneous memory system
nodes.description: Heterogeneous memory system: Systems that incorporate different types of memory, such as high-speed RAM, non-volatile memory (NVM), and specialized memory structures, to optimize performance and energy efficiency.

nodes.label: Shared memory versus distributed memory
nodes.title: Shared memory versus distributed memory
nodes.description: Shared memory versus distributed memory: Distinction between architectures where all processors share a common address space (shared memory) and those where each processor has its own local memory (distributed memory).

nodes.label: Volatile vs non‐volatile memory
nodes.title: Volatile vs non‐volatile memory
nodes.description: Volatile vs non‐volatile memory: Differentiating between memory types that require power to retain data (volatile) and those that can retain data without power (non-volatile), influencing system design and performance.

nodes.label: Coherence protocols
nodes.title: Coherence protocols
nodes.description: Coherence protocols: Mechanisms employed in multiprocessor systems to ensure that all processors have consistent views of shared memory, preventing data inconsistencies.

nodes.label: Domain‐Specific Architectures (DSAs)
nodes.title: Domain‐Specific Architectures (DSAs)
nodes.description: Domain‐Specific Architectures (DSAs): Architectures tailored for specific application domains, such as Machine Learning Accelerators optimized for neural network computations or In-Network Computing architectures that offload processing tasks to network devices.

nodes.label: Machine Learning Accelerator
nodes.title: Machine Learning Accelerator
nodes.description: Machine Learning Accelerator:

nodes.label: In‐networking computing
nodes.title: In‐networking computing
nodes.description: In‐networking computing:

nodes.label: Embedded systems for emerging applications
nodes.title: Embedded systems for emerging applications
nodes.description: Embedded systems for emerging applications: Systems designed to meet the requirements of specialized applications, often characterized by constraints such as size, power consumption, and real-time performance.

nodes.label: Neuromorphic computing
nodes.title: Neuromorphic computing
nodes.description: Neuromorphic computing: Computing paradigms inspired by the structure and function of the human brain, aiming to develop systems with low power consumption and high efficiency for tasks such as pattern recognition and sensory processing.

nodes.label: Packaging and integration solutions such as 3DIC and Chiplets
nodes.title: Packaging and integration solutions such as 3DIC and Chiplets
nodes.description: Packaging and integration solutions such as 3DIC and Chiplets: Advanced techniques for integrating multiple chips or functional units within a single package (3DIC) or combining discrete components (chiplets) to achieve higher performance, lower power consumption, and improved scalability.

nodes.label: Quantum Architectures
nodes.title: Quantum Architectures
nodes.description: Quantum Architectures:

nodes.label: Principles
nodes.title: Principles
nodes.description: Principles: Fundamental concepts including the wave-particle duality principle, which describes the behavior of particles like photons and electrons.

nodes.label: The wave‐particle duality principle
nodes.title: The wave‐particle duality principle
nodes.description: The wave‐particle duality principle:

nodes.label: The uncertainty principle in the double‐slit experiment
nodes.title: The uncertainty principle in the double‐slit experiment
nodes.description: The uncertainty principle in the double‐slit experiment: The Uncertainty Principle: Introduced by the double-slit experiment, stating that certain pairs of physical properties, like position and momentum, cannot be simultaneously measured with arbitrary precision.

nodes.label: What is a Qubit? Superposition and measurement. Photons as qubits.
nodes.title: What is a Qubit? Superposition and measurement. Photons as qubits.
nodes.description: What is a Qubit? Superposition and measurement. Photons as qubits.: Qubit: The basic unit of quantum information, analogous to the classical bit but capable of existing in a superposition of states until measured. Superposition and Measurement: Qubits can exist in multiple states simultaneously, known as superposition, until measured, at which point they collapse to a definite state.

nodes.label: Systems of twqubits. Entanglement. Bell states. The No‐Signaling theorem.
nodes.title: Systems of twqubits. Entanglement. Bell states. The No‐Signaling theorem.
nodes.description: Systems of twqubits. Entanglement. Bell states. The No‐Signaling theorem.: The phenomenon where qubits become correlated in such a way that the state of one qubit is dependent on the state of another, even when separated by large distances.

nodes.label: Axioms of QM: superposition principle, measurement axiom, unitary evolution
nodes.title: Axioms of QM: superposition principle, measurement axiom, unitary evolution
nodes.description: Axioms of QM: superposition principle, measurement axiom, unitary evolution: Principles governing the behavior of quantum systems, including the superposition principle, measurement axiom, and unitary evolution.

nodes.label: Single qubit gates for the circuit model of quantum computation: X, Z, H.
nodes.title: Single qubit gates for the circuit model of quantum computation: X, Z, H.
nodes.description: Single qubit gates for the circuit model of quantum computation: X, Z, H.: Basic quantum operations used in quantum circuits, such as X (bit-flip), Z (phase-flip), and H (Hadamard) gates.

nodes.label: Two-qubit gates and tensor products. Working with matrices.
nodes.title: Two-qubit gates and tensor products. Working with matrices.
nodes.description: Two-qubit gates and tensor products. Working with matrices.: Quantum operations that act on pairs of qubits, typically implemented using tensor products and matrices.

nodes.label: The No‐Cloning Theorem. The Quantum Teleportation protocol.
nodes.title: The No‐Cloning Theorem. The Quantum Teleportation protocol.
nodes.description: The No‐Cloning Theorem. The Quantum Teleportation protocol.: A fundamental principle stating that it is impossible to create an identical copy of an arbitrary unknown quantum state.Quantum Teleportation: A protocol that allows the transfer of quantum information from one qubit to another over long distances without physically transmitting the qubit itself.

nodes.label: Algorithms
nodes.title: Algorithms
nodes.description: Algorithms:

nodes.label: Simple quantum algorithms: Bernstein‐Vazirani, Simon’s algorithm.
nodes.title: Simple quantum algorithms: Bernstein‐Vazirani, Simon’s algorithm.
nodes.description: Simple quantum algorithms: Bernstein‐Vazirani, Simon’s algorithm.: Bernstein-Vazirani and Simon's algorithm, which demonstrate the power of quantum computing in solving certain problems more efficiently than classical computers.

nodes.label: Implementing Deutsch‐Josza with Mach‐Zehnder Interferometers.
nodes.title: Implementing Deutsch‐Josza with Mach‐Zehnder Interferometers.
nodes.description: Implementing Deutsch‐Josza with Mach‐Zehnder Interferometers.: Using Mach-Zehnder Interferometers to realize the Deutsch-Josza algorithm, a demonstration of quantum parallelism.

nodes.label: Quantum factoring (Shor’s Algorithm)
nodes.title: Quantum factoring (Shor’s Algorithm)
nodes.description: Quantum factoring (Shor’s Algorithm): Shor's algorithm is a quantum algorithm for integer factorization, which threatens current cryptographic systems relying on the difficulty of factoring large numbers.

nodes.label: Quantum search (Grover’s Algorithm)
nodes.title: Quantum search (Grover’s Algorithm)
nodes.description: Quantum search (Grover’s Algorithm): Grover's algorithm provides a quadratic speedup over classical algorithms for unstructured search problems.

nodes.label: Implementation aspects
nodes.title: Implementation aspects
nodes.description: Implementation aspects: Discussing the physical realization of qubits, the fundamental units of quantum information, and the challenges of classical control of a Quantum Processing Unit (QPU).

nodes.label: The physical implementation of qubits
nodes.title: The physical implementation of qubits
nodes.description: The physical implementation of qubits : there are currently nine qubit modalities

nodes.label: Classical control of a Quantum Processing Unit (QPU)
nodes.title: Classical control of a Quantum Processing Unit (QPU)
nodes.description: Classical control of a Quantum Processing Unit (QPU):

nodes.label: Error mitigation and control. NISQ and beyond.
nodes.title: Error mitigation and control. NISQ and beyond.
nodes.description: Error mitigation and control. NISQ and beyond.: Techniques for mitigating errors in quantum computations, particularly important in the era of Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices.

nodes.label: Emerging Applications
nodes.title: Emerging Applications
nodes.description: Emerging Applications: Exploring post-quantum encryption, the potential of the Quantum Internet for secure communication, and the promise of adiabatic quantum computation (AQC) and quantum annealing for optimization problems.

nodes.label: Post‐quantum encryption
nodes.title: Post‐quantum encryption
nodes.description: Post‐quantum encryption:

nodes.label: The Quantum Internet
nodes.title: The Quantum Internet
nodes.description: The Quantum Internet:

nodes.label: Adiabatic quantum computation (AQC) and quantum annealing
nodes.title: Adiabatic quantum computation (AQC) and quantum annealing
nodes.description: Adiabatic quantum computation (AQC) and quantum annealing:
